DataElement.preferredName: Wilms Tumor Related Clinical Syndrome Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term for a syndrome or collection of signs/symptoms associated with Wilms Tumor known at time of protocol registration.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Wilms Tumor Related Clinical Syndrome Occurrence
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix._A state of connectedness between people, objects, or events; to be associated or connected with something._Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients._a set of symptoms, usually three or more, which occur together and characterize a particular pathological state; for thorough searching see the Permuted Term Index for specific syndromes._An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix.:Related; connected or associated.:Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients.:a set of symptoms, usually three or more, which occur together and characterize a particular pathological state; for thorough searching see the Permuted Term Index for specific syndromes.

Concepts.definition: An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix.
A state of connectedness between people, objects, or events; to be associated or connected with something.
Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.
A group of signs, symptoms, and clinicopathological characteristics that may or may not have a genetic basis and collectively define an abnormal condition.

Property.preferredDefinition: Occurrence; an instance of something happening.

Concepts.definition: An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: An embryonal neoplasm characterized by the presence of epithelial, mesenchymal, and blastema components. The vast majority of cases arise from the kidney. A small number of cases with morphologic features resembling Wilms tumor of the kidney have been reported arising from the ovary and the cervix._Having to do with the examination and treatment of patients._a set of symptoms, usually three or more, which occur together and characterize a particular pathological state; for thorough searching see the Permuted Term Index for specific syndromes._The words or language units by which a thing is known.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare congenital syndrome caused by mutations in the WT1 gene. It is characterized by the presence of congenital nephropathy (diffuse mesangial sclerosis), Wilms tumor, and intersex disorders.

Concepts.definition: A rare congenital syndrome caused by mutations in the WT1 gene. It is characterized by the presence of congenital nephropathy (diffuse mesangial sclerosis), Wilms tumor, and intersex disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A very rare congenital condition involving the complex of Wilms' tumor, aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, and mental retardation. Wilms Tumor-Aniridia-Genitourinary Anomalies-Mental Retardation (WAGR) syndrome involves deletions of several adjacent genes in chromosome region 11p13. Two or more of the four conditions must be present for an individual to be diagnosed with WAGR Syndrome. The clinical picture varies, depending upon the combination of abnormalities.

Concepts.definition: A very rare congenital condition involving the complex of Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, and mental retardation. Wilms Tumor-Aniridia-Genitourinary Anomalies-Mental Retardation (WAGR) syndrome involves deletions of several adjacent genes in chromosome region 11p13. Two or more of the four conditions must be present for an individual to be diagnosed with WAGR Syndrome. The clinical picture varies, depending upon the combination of abnormalities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding indicating the presence of greater than normal asymmetry between the right and left sides of the body. The asymmetry may be manifested in the entire side or part of it.

Concepts.definition: A finding indicating the presence of greater than normal asymmetry between the right and left sides of the body. The asymmetry may be manifested in the entire side or part of it.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A genetic syndrome caused by abnormalities in chromosome 11.  It is characterized by large birth weight, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, ear abnormalities, and hypoglycemia.  Patients with this syndrome have an increased risk of developing embryonal tumors (gonadoblastoma, hepatoblastoma, Wilms tumor, Rhabdomyosarcoma) and adrenal cortex carcinomas.

Concepts.definition: A genetic syndrome caused by abnormalities in chromosome 11. It is characterized by large birth weight, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, ear abnormalities, and hypoglycemia. Patients with this syndrome have an increased risk of developing embryonal tumors (gonadoblastoma, hepatoblastoma, Wilms tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma) and adrenal cortex carcinomas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.
